newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: C.BANK REGISTERS SAVINGS BANK'S NEW CAPITAL.
newsitem.headline: C.BANK REGISTERS SAVINGS BANK'S NEW CAPITAL.

text.p: Lithuania's central bank said on Thursday it had registered 20 million litas in fresh share capital in the state-run Lithuanian Savings Bank.

"The board of the Bank of Lithuania registered a share capital increase in Lithuanian Savings Bank to 60 million litas from 40 million litas and the corresponding changes to its statute," the central bank said in a statement.
"The whole issue have been sucessfully distributed already," Daiva Rachkauskiene, the head of Savings Bank's brokerage house, told Reuters.
She also said that after the share capital boost the state maintained its 74.25 percent stake in the bank.
"I think that the shares of the new issue will start being traded on the Vilnius bourse at the end of June," Rachkauskiene added.
Lithuanian Savings Bank is one of the biggest banks in the country in term of assets.
Unlike the country's other two large state-owned banks, it has not been slated for privatisation.
The bank reported a 30 million litas net profit for 1996 after posting 39 million litas in losses the previous year.
It also said that it had a 1.7 million litas net profit in the first quarter of 1997.
